explosives.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data on an exothermic decomposition energy.

flammable_liquids.rationale: UNRTDG No. 2740, Class: 3; PG I. Flash point: -8.3degC. Boiling point 87.5degC

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Since it is not classified as UNRTDG class 4.2 PG I and the ignition points was 196 degC (ICSC (J), (2004)), it was presupposed that it does not ignite spontaneously even if it contacts the air of normal temperatures.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metaloids(B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: It is a moderate strong bases (ICSC (J) (2004)). However, there is no metal corrosion data and it cannot be classified.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: SPECIES: Rat ENDPOINT: LD50 VALUE: 32 mg/kg REFERENCE SOURCE: PATTY (4th, 1994)

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on rat LD50 value: 183mg/kg and rabbit LD50 value: 93mg/kg (ACGIH 7th, 2001, PATTY 4th, 1994), the rabbit lower value was adopted and it was set as Category 2.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on rat LC50 (4 hours) values: 74ppm and 78ppm (equivalent of 0.14mg/L and 0.15mg/L) (ACGIH 7th, 2001, PATTY 4th, 1994) which vapor pressure indicate steam with almost no mist, it was classified as Category 1 by the ppm concentration standard.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description that erythema and edema were observed in dog skin application test, though the exposure time was unknown (ACGIH (7th, 2004) and PATTY (4th, 1994)) and that there is possibility of severe damage on human skin (PATTY (4th, 1994)), it was classified as Category 2.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: It was set as Category 2A from description that damage serious to an eye may be seen by the humans of PATTY (4th, 1994).

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitization: Classification not possible; Skin sensitization: Classification not possible
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respirator: No data Skin: Although classified into Sh according to DFG, since there was no evidence that hypersensitivity was induced by skin contacts by humans, it did not meet the judgment criteria and it was decided not to be classified due to insufficiency of data.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: The substance is regarded as outside the categories. Because there are negative results from the dominant lethal tests in mice, which are in vivo multi-generation mutagenicity tests using germ cells (ACGIH (7th, 2001), PATTY (4th, 1994)).

carcinogenicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of causing cancer (state route of exposure if it is conclusively proven that no other routes of exposure cause the hazard)
carcinogenicity.rationale: Since it was classified into A3 (ACGIH 7th, 2001) according to ACGIH, it was set as Category 2.

toxic_to_reproduction.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the undorn child
toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Since although there was no descriptions about general toxicity of parent animals, there is the description that there is fetal malformation in oral administration test to pregnancy mouse and rabbit (HSDB (2005)), it is classified into the Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs (blood system, nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Due to the descriptions that the effect on the blood was observed in human inhalation exposure example in PATTY (4th, 1994), that the convulsion was observed in the range of guidance value of Category 1 in the oral study using rat, and that the effect on the nervous system was observed in the inhalation exposure test using mouse with unknown concentrations. So it was classified into Category 1 (blood, nervous system) from description that .

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (blood vessels, liver, kidneys, respiratory organs, adrenal)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (blood vessels, liver, kidneys, respiratory organs, adrenal) through prolonged or repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: It is classfied in Category 1 (blood, liver, kidney, respiratory organs, adrenal gland) from description in ACGIH (7th, 2001) that the influence on liver, the kidney, respiratory organs, or the adrenal gland were seen with the concentration of the guidance value range of Category 1 in the test which carried out inhalation exposure, over a long-term to the rat, the mouse, the dog, hamster, or ape.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 96-hour LC50=2580microg/Lof fishes (Guppy) (AQUIRE, 2003) .

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 2, since acute toxicity was Category 2, and not rapidly degrading (BOD: 0% (existing chemical safety inspections data)), though supposed less bio-accumulative (log Kow=-1.05(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)).
